comments.commentBody:
Mr. Goldstein,

You get the gold star of the day! Love the article.

In Chicago we have loads of "Lonnie Loosies" especially on the South side. The downside to all of this (besides me giving up a 9.15 pack a day habit, only joking) is the jailing of these entrepreneurs. Yes, I rather have someone like Lonnie dealing this vice than going back to robbing. The city and state governments have got to find a way to work with such individuals. Evidently he is reformed but can't find work. So he makes it and what does the government do? Arrest him again and again. So there's the lost taxes (me paying for his arrests, too) that could be made by having Lonnie & Co. pay for a sellers license or whatever pertaining to cigarettes. And to those who say that they won't do it, pffft I bet you a "loosie" or two they would.

I lived in Cairo Egypt for almost two years.  Cigarettes are only one of many items that are sold in this fashion.  Drugstores will sell one aspirin to their customers.  I do not know anything about Egypt's tax laws but I do know that many Egyptian could not afford to buy a whole bottle of aspirin when they only needed one.

“We don’t allow people to sell drugs on this block,” he said. “We just don’t allow it.”

How ironic. What the heck do they think cigarets are? The biggest drug ever!

There is something that is just COOL about this story...It's capitalism at it's finest...And the guy turned his life around...Sure, you could argue all that, but why? Isn't there enough negative to go around...

Mr. Warner is a devout adherent to the sacred practice of Capitalism.  He is also street smart and his survival instincts are firmly in place.  You may not like what he's doing but you have to admire his sense of entrepreneurship.  It's the American way!

If Wall Street bankers can pull a fast one to the tune of billions of dollars from hardworking Americans and still be allowed to walk the streets, then Lonnie can sell his "loosies" while riding a  white stallion through Manhattan as far as I'm concerned.

Lonnie Loosie Fans:

The reason that people like Lonnie can't be allowed to ply their trade is that regulations exist for a reason. Please accept my apologies in advance: I'm a law student.

If you think some affable guy should be able to sell loose cigarettes in blatant disregard of the law, you are saying that some especially attractive girl should be able to sell her body, some rakish strip miner should be able to rape the earth and affect his neighbors' health, that some organic poppy farmer should be able to produce boutique heroin for tasteful aesthetes, or that some otherwise-upstanding truckdriver should be allowed to usher illegal immigrants into our country. I'm all for stripping unnecessary oversight, but this not an example of that...there are good reasons for not having anyone who has access to cigarettes being allowed to sell them as they can.

Beyond that, the tax on cigarettes subsidizes the services that NYers enjoy, and NY's legislature is unwilling to tax more sensical things like corporate earnings or the profits hedge fund managers make. In this tricky political climate where things HAVE to get paid for and no one is willing to make the people who have money step up, the poor cigarette smokers are getting milked...but it wouldn't work if they didn't smoke, and the fact that they choose to smoke impacts the NYC public health system.

You might think that $12.50 is ridiculous, and I agree...but only because my first pack of cigarettes was $2.00, and I bought it when I was 16. I quit after my first pack. However, I look forward to the day when cigarettes are a curious relic, like bloodletting. It's a stupid, horrible, addictive habit, and I was horrified that Obama got the FDA into the business of policing their standards as they have no positive attributes to justify their place in our society.

Furthermore, Lonnie is selling something without oversight...we can assume he is not selling cigarettes to minors because he seems so charming, but who really knows? He flirts with women, saying they shouldn't smoke..and then sells them Newports, with their fiberglass additives. Does he do the same with teenage basketball players who want a butt after practice? Along these lines, can we assume that he reports and is being taxed on his black market income?

I think Lonnie is an engaging person, but there is no reason to wish that such people are allowed to skirt employment and engagement with society that falls within its prescribed norms.
Legislating morality inevitably leads to so-called criminal activity such as this. This man is committing civil disobedience in response to an unjust moral law.

Beneluxer, you are so wrong.
What does prostitution have to do with marketing in small scale? Some regulations are just way beyond reality. Wake up!

I dont like cigarettes. I quite smoking almost twelve years ago, and now I feel great. I dont want other people smoking either, but, I dont want a totalitarian regime running the evil empire state. I think it is absolutely ludicrous that these people are prosecuted for a simple act of capatalism, a smart one at that. If the supermarket can sell me one or two cans of soup out of a case they buy, then these guys can sell single cigarettes! The cigarettes are legal, new york is unconstitutional and a downright prison.
If you want to quite smoking, its easier than you think. Just quite cold turkey. Its really not bad. I did it without any drug-like pangs. I just got over having something in my hand and mouth in a couple of days. It really is easier than they say. Imagine the money you will save, really, get out your calculator and figure it out. The first week of saving, buy something like a hobby toy to reward yourself. That will give you satisfaction.
Leave New York for freedom. This is the scary reality of the future of America.

Following up on my prior comment, I forgot he didnt pay taxes on the cigarettes. Sorry about that. Then again, 300 percent taxation doesnt sound legal either. I say, drop the single sales prosection provided the guys buy legitimate packs of cigarettes and raises prices slightly to account for it. He would still sell and make a profit.

A dealer is, as,a dealer does, just depends on the drug. This only proves that drug laws have nothing to do with protecting society, but everything to do with collecting taxes. Legalize drugs and watch the money roll in.

If we (the police/the US citizens) are going to arrest Mr. Loosie why are we not arresting those individuals purchasing the individual cigarettes? Isn't it illegal to purchase something that is illegally sold? Not sure but it works that way with prostitution, right? The prostitute, the pimp, and the john all get tossed into the can, so why not the cigarette salesman, the watchers, the suppliers, the seedy smokers?

It's also rather fascinating that there is a big news story about selling cigarettes on the street "The Brisk, Shady Sale of ‘Loosies’" Sounds like someone best scoop it up and make a reality tv show about it. Right? Then our friend can be doing honest work.

Whatever happened to the honor of catching and arresting someone doing great harm to the community? It is shameful when there is so much harm is being done in our communities? Catching individuals who falsify and sell their personal interest as common good action? They fool people into hopes of great gain at the expense of others. I believe very few of those people have ever seen the inside of a jail cell on Riker's Island. But the bright side is both for Mr. Loosie and for New York – it might be that this story creates yet another "tourist attraction" which ultimately brings more people into New York to gawk at the almost disappeared seedy, yet interesting, side of Manhattan's streets. What would be brilliant is that someone in this article who is telling us how bad this act is would actually hire him to work an “honest” job and initiate him into the honest working person’s system.

What happened to helping our neighbors and sharing the wealth? Or has that become a socialist concept? Or could it even be considered an ethical or moral dilemma? We are too darn advanced in the US to really focus on this sort of element when there is a “great depression” at work here. Also, the depression is hitting the globe and everyone is at risk.

Are we so greatly devoid of honor that we can not see one man selling individual cigarettes as an entrepreneurial act and celebrate capitalism and one man’s struggle to earn money, somewhat honestly, that will offer him a higher quality food than a dollar slice of pizza. It’s good he’s not stealing someone else’s hard earned money or goods – I’m thinking there are lots of middle class people doing things they wouldn’t normally do at this time in their life.

Taxes? How did Rockefeller get his money – hmmmm? Wasn’t that from not paying taxes on liquor? How about those corporate accountants and lawyers who work non-stop to find those tax evading loop holes? Remember, Judge not lest you be judged – lots of US citizen’s are trying their darnedest to get rich and avoid taxes – they just do it differently and hope not to get caught. And what about War, it’s interesting how this can escalate…I’m sure everyone could do this for days. We all have an ax to grind so why not just arrest the guy cuz he’s doing something illegal – not paying taxes on a luxury, lung polluting, murderous item.

I don't understand why those who chose to tax cigarettes at such an exhorbanent amount, didn't realize that this would happen.
Ruth Beazer
Jail for this?  Oh, come on.  California gave a "repeat criminal" 50 YEARS for stealing 3 videotapes, @ $45,000 per year, and they wonder why they're broke?

I laughed hard. This person has a zest for life; a philosophy on life so foreign to Americans (he is not just a consumer); he is happy to have his senses at a maximum and not be in the semi-awake state that most of us are most of the time; he is graceful; and he makes the most of what life has thrown at him. And that makes him a true American!

On a side note, Mayor Bloomberg is right on keeping cigarettes and cigarette smoke out of as many places (and people) and possible.

When the government becomes burdensome, people find a way to unburden themselves from the government.

There is nothing unethical about resisting an oppressive regime, such as that of the federal and local governments in these United States, or with making enough to live off in the process.

If the government can not or will not deliver what the people want and deserve, or actively begins to infringe on citizen's reasonable desires, then it behooves the criminals to step in and replace the government in whole or part. (and what is the government if not the most locally powerful group of criminals? try not paying your taxes to the USGov _OR_ the Mafia and let me know how it works out for you)

Also: What do you expect him to do for a living? You can't get a job in this country with any sort of criminal record. You just can't. You expect him to eat and drink the air? It needs to change, but things will get worse before they get better.(I estimate 200-300 years before we recover our civil society)
Lonnie's claim to be earning $120 - $150 in a typical day is probably much too low. $500+/day might be nearer to the truth. This is something the reporter should have investigated.
I was taught that ignorance is no excuse for breaking the law.

My daughter and her husband, both teachers, decided to take a post-masters online class from highly rated University of Maryland. They were disappointed by the low level of expectation from on-line students, the poor quality of instruction and the lack of interaction among students via online.

They could hardly wait for the semester to end this Mickey Mouse class and go offline.

I am currently teaching in week 10 of 14 weeks of a pre-Freshman level English composition course at an inner-city community college in the San Francisco Bay Area. I can personally attest to the failure of this online learning mode for remedial students in a skill-based course such as writing. From 30 original students, only 9 have actively survived to this week. The rest have disappeared for various reasons, including illness, accident, learning disabilities, laziness, inability to function online, and disinterest in our work. These 9 students may or may not pass; none passed the in-class mid-term this week. I see them only 2 hours/week in this "hybrid" course, and it simply isn't enough to help students who struggle in the mostly under-class (first in their family in college, born of immigrants, over 30 years old, etc.). They need my personal help and aren't getting it. Even though I am on-line 7 days/week via email to answer questions, and they have a decent textbook, it isn't enough. They need personal attention, hand-holding, guidance and yes, teaching, and it isn't happening. Every teacher at my school whom I ask says they would never teach such a class if they could help it. The dean, an old friend, tells me confidentially she knows this doesn't work, but the administration insists this is the "wave of the future". Good luck to all of you teachers in this mode, and all of your students, who if they are anything like mine, are struggling. For those who want to make policy and financial decisions about the value of this education, I invite you to my class to see the results: there aren't any. I suppose 3 or 4 of my students may pass this semester, a high investment of my salary for very few successes. I'll never teach this kind of class again, and I am ashamed I can't help my students more.

I have written extremely condemning comments about Saif Al Islam Qaddafi. He said things with a war criminal twinge. However, I noticed he changed his ideas recently. He is very clever, and talks a lot. So he makes a plausible interlocutor for an orderly surrender of power of the Qaddafi clan, in the ares it still controls.

Saif Al Islam could be party to order keeping while preparing for an orderly transition to a more democratic regime. But everything should be in writing, and an arrangement similar to the one in Ivory Coast, with muscular UN supervision, put in place. That to avoid the sort of situation as in Ivory Coast, where an unelected president still refuses to leave, 10 years later. And the possibility to use force to remedy such an evolution, should it occur, as is finally presently done in Ivory Coast.
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/
If those Libyans had an ounce of sense they would let US take care of the whole shebang!

Great find.

It seems to me that, on an actuarial basis, Medicare should be required to balance its budget. Wouldn't such a requirement be a great negotiating position for Medicare to bargain with providers so that only proven, effective treatments are covered? How about fewer expensive but mostly unnecessary MRIs for every headache.. fewer expensive joint surgeries and more low-cost orthotics?

The long-run cost problem with containing costs is that people want to spend on care that promises even a tiny increase in lifespan or quality of life, no matter what the cost. Over time, such care transitions from a novelty to a necessity. Since all the low-hanging fruit is discovered, new and major medical advances are likely to come about through major outlays in fancy equipment, biotechnology, and pharmaceuticals. All of which are expensive.

I LOVE the Summer Triangle....in my habit of going for a late evening walk, I almost always look up into the sky to see if I can spot it. Deneb, Altair and Vega......it is quite distinctive. You can see it here:

http://www.souledout.org/nightsky/summertriangle/summertriangle.html

(that link was my ASTRAL projection hehe)

Gareth Bain! loved your comments, hello South AFrica from BC Canada!
